results.title: Prime suspect 3
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Paul Marcus and David Drury
results.brief_description: DCI Tennison (Helen Mirren) has made it in a man’s world and secured the position of a high ranking policewoman. In this third instalment of Lynda La Plante’s series Tennison is given the assignment of cleaning up the murky world of prostitutes, or “rent boys”, due to public pressure about the standard of morality in Soho- Operation Contract. The nature of her assignment quickly changes tack when one of the boys perishes in a suspicious fire. Strange details begin to emerge, such as forensic evidence that the victim was unconscious when the fire started and someone called an ambulance to the flat that night The suspects soon mount- the sleazy pimp, the head of a centre for troubled boys, and a respected police official. Tennison’s personal life is not without upheaval during the investigation as an old flame enters the scene, causing her to question life’s decisions. As Tennison leads her investigative team into an underworld populated by paedophiles, pornographic photography, transvestites and abuse, the shocking truth is revealed and Helen must make an important decision. Cast includes Vera Reynolds, David Thewlis, Danny Dyer, Tom Bell and Ciaran Hinds.

results.title: Prime suspect
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Don Leaver and Christopher Menaul
results.brief_description: The first episode of the award winning series written by Lynda La Plante. In the early hours of a winter morning the body of a brutally murdered young woman is discovered in a small bedsit. DCI Shefford is put in charge of the investigation, however the situation quickly changes when he suffers a massive heart attack and is replaced by the ambitious Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren). DCI Tennison soon discovers the difficulties of heading a homicide enquiry. Not only do her male colleagues resent the fact that she is a woman and do all they can to obstruct her, but the case itself is particularly difficult when it comes to charging the suspect George Marlow (John Bowe). Although Tennison and her team are convinced of the killer, they are unable to prove it until a second body is found and what started as a single murder develops into an investigation stretching back over ten years and implicating police officials. Cast includes Tom Bell, Zoe Wanamaker, John Benfield, Brian Pringle, Tom Wilkinson and a brief appearance by Ralph Fiennes.

results.title: Primary sources: the raw material of history
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introduction to History”.
The film uses London as a place to show how different primary sources can be used to study its history. The primary sources include an excavated Roman bath-house, early documents, pottery, maps, paintings, business records and archival film.

results.title: Primary media studies
results.creator_credit: Film Media Studies, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Stephen Skok
results.brief_description: Indicates various types of activities that could be included in a primary media studies course. Shows hand drawing on film, making storyboards, exercises in persistence of vision, stimuli for creative writing, drama with video and script development.

results.title: Primary health care: a team approach
results.creator_credit: NBC Films, Robert Kruger, Pierre Henfrey and Ray Poole
results.brief_description: A film showing the health care provided in the Lisson Grove Health Centre, opened in 1978. Shows doctors, ward sisters, and district nurses at work and the value of having various health care workers under the same roof to make team work easier.

results.title: Primary education in England
results.brief_description: The Sea Mills Infant School in Bristol, one of the leading infant schools in England, is seen as an extension of the environment of home and family. This documentary film follows the interaction of teacher and children as the children’s energies and interests are directed toward self-selected learning activities. Suitable for teacher training. Narrated by Kathleen Brearley Andrews.

results.title: Primary colors
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Mutual Film Company and Mike Nichols
results.brief_description: Jack Stanton is a governor from a small southern state who, while sincere in his devotion to the American people, is nevertheless plagued by scandal at every twist on the campaign trail to the presidency. Includes music score by Ry Cooder. Cast includes John Travolta, Emma Thompson, Billy Bob Thornton, Kathy Bates, Adrian Lester, Larry Hagman and Diane Ladd.

results.title: Primary adventure
results.brief_description: Made as part of the Inner London Education Authority’s contribution to the commemoration of the centenary of the Forster Education Act of 1870. The film shows modern methods of teaching and learning in primary schools during 1970.

results.title: Priit Parn: selected films
results.brief_description: This tape features three films from the award winning Estonian animation director and political cartoonist, Priit Parn. An artist who uses animation to satirise and parody the old Soviet system and the conflicting outcomes of Perestroika. His films are rich with repetition and allusion, and as with much Eastern European animation, is laden with symbolism. “Time out” follows the antics of a hero cat (produced by Hille Koosk); “Breakfast on the grass” provides a parallel with Manet’s work and reveals bureaucracy at its most malign (produced by Tallinnfilm); “Hotel E” explores the process of Glasnost, using a hotel setting as a metaphor for East and West (produced by Olav Osolin).

results.title: Priest
results.creator_credit: Electric Pictures (Aust), PolyGram Filmed Entertainment, BBC, Josephine Ward, George Faber and Antonia Bird
results.brief_description: A young priest tests his faith and vocation when assigned to a working class Parish in Liverpool. When a teenage girl confesses of her father’s incestuous advances, he is torn by the rituals of a Church which swears him to silence and to which he owes obedience, and his innate sense of justice. This conflict is compounded by his struggle with his own desires and sexuality as he enters into an illicit homosexual relationship. Linus Roache is excellent and well supported by a cast including Tom Wilkinson, Cathy Tyson and Robert Carlyle. “Priest” does not seek to attack organised religion; instead it offers a window into the heart and mind of a believer who struggles daily with his faith and vocation to find a true path.
